Schedule

Classes run from 8:00 to 9:00 PM EDT on Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays.

Key resources: R for Data Science (2e) by Hadley Wickham, Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel, and Garrett Grolemund, Preceptor’s Primer for Bayesian Data Science by David Kane and their associated tutorials. Homework should be completed before the class meeting for which it is assigned. We also reference Analyzing US Census Data: Methods, Maps, and Models in R by Kyle Walker.

See the home pages for the r4ds.tutorials, all.primer.tutorials, and tidycensus.tutorials for installation instructions.

Always reinstall the relevant package before starting a new tutorial. We are always fixing mistakes. You want to use the latest version.

Completed tutorials are submitted via this Google form. If you do not complete the tutorials on time, you will be removed from the class. Send in your tutorial answers saved in html format. Please try to ensure that the name of the file is the default name, like getting-started_answers.html. Avoid using the name which will be assigned to the file if you download the same answers once or twice, stuff like getting-started_answers (2).html. You can just change the name of the file by hand if this happens.

Week 1: Visualization

Looking at the data is the first step in data science.

Monday

  • Read Getting Started and follow all the associated instructions. We will do the Getting Started tutorial from the tutorial.helpers package together in class. When you complete the Getting Started tutorial, submit your answers via this Google form.

Wednesday

  • Read Chapters 1 through 4 from R for Data Science (2e).

  • From the r4ds.tutorials package, complete the associated tutorials: Introduction, Data Visualization, RStudio and Code, and Data Transformation.

Thursday

  • Read Chapters 5, 6 and 8 from R for Data Science (2e).

  • From the r4ds.tutorials package, complete the associated tutorials: RStudio and Github, Data Tidying and Data Import tutorials.

Reminder: All work must be completed before class. Failure to submit your tutorial answers will result in you being removed from the course. It is not fair to your fellow students, with whom you will be working in small groups, for you to not be prepared for class.

Week 2: Wrangling

Now that we know how to visualize data that is already clean, we need to learn how to clean up messy data.

Monday

  • Read Chapters 9, 10, 11 and 12 from R for Data Science (2e).

  • From the r4ds.tutorials package, complete the Terminal tutorial. Also complete the tutorials associated with the readings: Getting Help, Layers, Exploratory Data Analysis, and Communication. Note that the Terminal tutorial is at the end of the r4ds.tutorials collection.

Wednesday

  • Read chapters 13, 14, 15 and 16 from R for Data Science (2e).

  • From the r4ds.tutorials package, complete the associated tutorials: Logical, Numbers, Strings, and Regular Expressions.

Thursday

  • Read chapters 17, 18, 19 and 29 from R for Data Science (2e).

  • From the r4ds.tutorials package, complete the associated tutorials: Factors, Dates and times, Missing values, and Joins.

Week 3: Data

Now that we know how to clean and organize messy data, we need to learn how to get some data.

Monday

  • Read chapters 21, 22 and 23 from R for Data Science (2e).

  • From the r4ds.tutorials package, complete the associated tutorials: Spreadsheets, Databases, and Arrow.

Wednesday

  • Read the Style Guide.

  • Read chapters 7, 24 and 25 from R for Data Science (2e).

  • From the r4ds.tutorials package, complete the associated tutorials: Quarto Websites, Hierarchical data and Web scraping.

  • Determine the data source you will use for your final project. Don’t come to class without one!

Thursday

  • From the tidycensus.tutorials package, complete: Census Data I, Census Data II and API Key.

Week 4: Models

Monday

  • Read Chapter 4 Rubin Causal Model. Focus on sections 4.1, 4.2 and 4.4.

  • From the all.primer.tutorials package, complete Rubin Causal Model - Overview tutorial.

Wednesday

  • Read Chapter 5 Probability. Focus on sections 5.1, 5.2, 5.7, and 5.8.

  • From the all.primer.tutorials package, complete Probability - Overview tutorial.

Thursday

  • Read Chapter 6 One Parameter. Focus on sections 6.3 and 6.4.

  • From the all.primer.tutorials package, complete One Parameter - Overview tutorial.

Week 5: Inference

Monday

  • Read Chapter 7 Two Parameters.

  • From the all.primer.tutorials package, complete Two Parameters - Overview tutorial.

Wednesday

  • Read Chapter 8 Three Parameters.

  • From the all.primer.tutorials package, complete Three Parameters - Overview tutorial.

Thursday

  • Read Chapter 9 Four Parameters.

  • From the all.primer.tutorials package, complete Four Parameters - Overview tutorial.

Week 6: Projects

The last week will consist of projects that the students will make. Do you love soccer or wine or NYC politics? The final project provides you with an opportunity to study that topic in depth. Your final project will be, for most of you, the first item in your professional portfolio, something so impressive that you will be eager to show it to graduate schools or potential employers.

Monday

  • Complete Final Project tutorial before class, or you will be removed the course. There are no extensions for this assignment.

  • You must have a draft of your final project ready to go, including a Quarto website and your four sentence introduction.

Wednesday

  • Practice presentations and feedback. You must have your presentation ready to go!

Thursday

  • Final project presentations. You must invite someone.
